A new H-bond Ti-MOF-based catalyst via the post-modification method of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) was synthesized. The catalytic role of Ti-MOF-UR is based on hydrogen-bond interaction. Ti-MOF-UR was used to synthesize pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines that contain the biological nuclei of pyrazole, henna and coumarin. The structure of the synthesized catalyst as well as the pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives were approved by using various instrumental techniques such as melting point, FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HR-MS techniques. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords H-bond catalyst Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 Pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines Pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) have been considered as a new generation nanoreactors. Their unique properties, such as their crystalline nature, high surface area, high porosity and adjustable pore size, make these porous structures attractive materials for further research demand [1,2]. Also, MOFs are used in the fields of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), adsorption and desorption, purifications, gas storage, drug delivery, catalytic and photocatalytic application [3–7]. Variety in the choice of ligands, metal clusters and post-modification have made MOFs more feasible and designable. Recently, chemistry of MOFs has been developed by applying the metal element of MOFs ranges from s-block elements. In particular, MOFs that include transition metal groups are most predominant owing to the notable characteristics of p-block and d -block metals [8]. As a result, titanium is one of the famous metals which is used in metal-organic frameworks. The titanium metal-organic frameworks contain the linking of diverse (Ti-O) groups and organic linkers. Recently, H-bond catalysts are known as an effective method for the synthesis of organic mediators, because these catalysts are able to selectively bond and activate substrates during the reaction process through hydrogen bonding and also play the role of Lewis acid [9,10]. Several MOF-based H-bond catalysts derived from urea and thiourea molecules were prepared by direct synthesis or post-modification method [11–15]. Despite the great interest in such solid catalysts, studies on MOF-based multifunctional H-bond catalysts remain limited. In recent years, our research team has expanded the catalytic field of MOFs [16–23] and H-bond catalysts [24–27]. In continuing our research, we decided to join metal-organic frameworks based on titanium metal by linking with urea moiety through a post-modification method. In recent years, organonitrogen compounds have expanded greatly and form the basis of many pharmaceutical and biological structures and many studies have been done on these compounds [28,29]. An important group of N-heterocyclic scaffolds belong to the pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines family, which are present in the structure of many pharmaceutical and biological compounds and play an important role in the preparation of many natural products, functional materials and pharmaceutical agents [30,31]. Pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines are used in many products such as food flavorings, adhesives, medicines, rubber products, dyes, insecticides, vitamins and herbicides [32–34]. The compound 2-hydroxynaphthalene-1,4‑dione, or under the brand name henna, is one of the most widely used compounds in the medical and environmental fields. Henna is present in the structure of many medicinal compounds [35,36]. Due to its color properties, this substance is used in many environmental and health compounds to produce dyes, and henna forms the basis of many color compounds [37,38]. Fig. 1 shows a number of medicinal and biological compounds containing pyrazole, henna and coumarin moieties which have antibacterial, antiplatelet, antitumoral, anti-HIV, antifungal and antiparasitic properties [39–42]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods 2-Amino terephthalic acid (NH2-BDC, 95%), titanium tetraisopropanolate (TTIP, 99.8%) phenyl isocyanate (PhNCO, 98%), 2‑hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone (Henna, 98%), hydrazine (N2H4, 80%), 4′-chloroacetophenone (C8H7ClO) and various aromatic aldehyde derivatives (95%) were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich. Furthermore, Acetone (85%), ethanol (EtOH, 99%), ethyl acetate (EtOAc, 95%), n-hexane (95%), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%), and methanol (MeOH, 99%) were purchased from commercial sources without further purification. 2.2 Characterization The morphology of the obtained precursors from the different stages of the synthesis of the desired catalyst was characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) technique TESCAN MIRA-II (Czechia). Meanwhile, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and elemental mapping was carried out by the model TESCAN MIRA-II (Czechia). Moreover, the FT-IR technique model device) PerkinElmer Spectrum Version 10.02.00) was used to identify the functional groups of the different stages of catalyst. Finally, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) technique with a model device BELSORP-mini-II was utilized to determine the surface area and pore size of synthesized catalyst. 2.3 Preparation of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst MIL-125-NH2 was synthesized using the solvothermal method according to the previously reported procedure [43]. For this aim, titanium tetraisopropanolate (TTIP) (3 mmol, 0.855 g) and 2-amino terephthalic acid (NH2-BDC) (6 mmol, 1.10 g) were placed in a mixture of DMF (25 mL)/MeOH (25 mL) in a 100 mL beaker and stirred at room temperature for 5 min. The resulting solution was poured into 80 mL Teflon and placed at 150 °C for 24 h. The yellow precipitates were collected after the reaction was completed and washed several times with DMF and MeOH to remove the unreacted reagent and/or starting materials. The resulting powder was dried at 80 °C. In the following for the synthesis of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, MIL-125-NH2 (200 mg) was dispersed in CH3CN (10 mL) and phenyl isocyanate (5 mmol, 0.596 g) was added to it. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The suspension was poured into a 25 mL Teflon and placed at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the yellow solid was dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h to give title post-modified Ti-MOFs (Scheme 1). 2.4 Catalytic reaction After preparation of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, its catalytic application in the preparation of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives was investigated. To achieve this goal, raw material 3-(4-chlorophenyl)−1H-pyrazol-5-amine was initially synthesized according to the previously reported methods [44]. Then, for the synthesis of derivatives, 3-(4-chlorophenyl)−1H-pyrazol-5-amine (1 mmol, 0.193 g), 2-hydroxynaphthalene-1,4‑dione (1 mmol, 0.174 g) or 4‑hydroxy-2H-chromen-2-one (1 mmol, 0.162 g), various benzaldehyde derivatives (1 mmol) and 15 mg of Ti-MOF-UR as a catalyst were added in a 10 mL bottom flask. The reaction mixture was stirred under solvent-free condition at 110 °C. Progression of the reaction was followed by TLC technique. At the end of the reaction, the reaction mixture was allowed to cooled up to room temperature. Then, hot acetone (20 mL) was added to the reaction mixture to separate the catalyst. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the reaction solvent was evaporated. The precipitate was then washed several times with EtOH (for pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines) and EtOAc (for pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines) to obtain a pure product (Scheme 2). 2.5 Spectral data 7,8-Bis(4-chlorophenyl)−10,11-dihydro-5H-benzo[h]pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline-5,6(7H)‑dione (A1). Among the mentioned facts, titanium-based metal-organic frameworks are suitable candidates for various applications such as CO2 reduction, photocatalysis, and degradation of pollutants due to their optical photoredox and photosensitivities properties. So, the type of morphology and surface area of the Ti-MOF is a very important factor for its catalytic activity. For this reason, Ti-MOF is selected as a catalyst bed in this article. With this aim, the development of MOFs, H-bond catalyst and synthesis of heterocycles with, pyrazole, indole and henna moieties is the purpose of our research. Herein we decided to synthesize a new H-bond Ti-MOF-based catalyst for the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines [45]. 3.1 Catalyst preparation strategy As abovementioned, the design and synthesis of porous catalysts that are followed in our research team [16–23], in the present study, a new type of porous catalyst whose function is based on hydrogen bond donor was designed and synthesized. The Ti-MOF-UR preparation strategy as a new porous H-bond catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . Due to the reaction of NH2 group with phenyl isocyanate, urea composition is formed in its structure. Urea acts as a hydrogen bonding agent due to the presence of an amide group within its structure. The final structure of the catalyst was proved by various techniques such as EDX, elemental mapping, XRD, FT-IR, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (BET) and BJH analysis. Given the importance of expanding compounds with biological activity, this new catalyst prepared was used in the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives with pyrazole, henna and chromene moieties at 110 °C under solvent-free conditions (Scheme 2 ). The final structure of the products prepared according to this method was confirmed using melting point, FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HR-MS techniques. After successfully preparing Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, detailed physical characterization techniques were investigated to confirm the formation of catalyst. The FT-IR spectra of the final catalyst structure were compared with the structure of MIL-125(Ti)-NH2. The results are shown in Fig. 2 . The results show that MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 is the same as the previous report patterns and shows its proper synthesis [43]. Due to the addition of phenyl isocyanate during synthesis, the Ti-MOF structure has maintained its stability and this can be proved by observing their characteristic peaks in the final spectrum. The most important peaks belong to the NH2 functional group as well as the resonant carbonyl group. The presence of NH groups formed in the final structure of the catalyst confirms the formation of urea section. The crystalline structure of the obtained Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst was analyzed using the XRD pattern (Fig. 3 ). The MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 crystal pattern is in a good agreement with previous report [43]. Peaks of MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 exhibited 2 θ = 6.75°, 9.65°, 9.72°, 11.61°, 14.89°, 16.45°, 16.66°, 17.92°, 19.21°, 19.55°, 20.75°, 22.45°, 23.43° and 25.28° corresponding to diffraction lines (101), (200), (002), (211), (220), (310), (103), (222), (312), (213), (400), (004), (422) and (204). The Ti-MOF-UR crystal pattern shows that the early-stage crystal plates were not destroyed during synthesis. The new peaks created in the second stage are related to the formation of urea, which is created during the synthesis of the target catalyst. The changes made well indicate the formation of the final desired catalyst along with the stability of its crystalline plates. In another study, energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) technique was used to confirm the structure as well as elements in structure for MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 and Ti-MOF-UR (Fig. 4 ). According to the EDX analysis, the existence elements of O, C, N and Ti in structure of catalyst were approved. The results obtained by elemental mapping analysis correctly confirm the EDX results and prove the presence of elements in the catalyst and its uniform dispersion. The size and morphology of the synthesized catalyst surface was determined using SEM images) Fig. 5 ). The images show the circular plate morphologies for MIL-125(Ti)-NH2. After the addition of phenyl isocyanate, the morphology of MIL-125(Ti)-NH2 remained constant, so that is indicating the high stability of the catalyst. This type of morphology, due to the high surface area they create, provides suitable conditions for the reaction, which is one of the reasons for the high efficiency of the products can be the appropriate morphology of the catalyst. The N2 -adsorption/desorption isotherms of the Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, was measured by the BET method (Fig. 6 ). Based on the obtained results, the surface area was calculated based on the BET equation for Ti-MOF-UR, 180 m2g−1. Furthermore, the total pore volume for this catalyst indicated 0.305 cm3g−1. Meanwhile, the pore size distributions of Ti-MOF-UR based on the BJH plot are shown in Fig. 6. The average pore diameter for catalyst was 3.49 nm. This catalyst, with high surface area, can create more reactive sites to improve its catalytic activity, a feature that is well established based on the data has been proven in the synthesized catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity After synthesis of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, it was used for synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives. The catalytic performance of Ti-MOF-UR was well determined according to the results obtained. The reaction between, 3-(4-chlorophenyl)−1H-pyrazol-5-amine (1 mmol, 0.193 g), 4‑hydroxy-2H-chromen-2-one (1 mmol, 0.162 g) and 4‑chloro benzaldehyde (1 mmol, 0.141 g) were used as a model reaction for the synthesis 10,11-bis(4-chlorophenyl)chromeno[3,4-b]pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridin-6(8H)-one (1A). The model reaction was studied by using several solvents such as CH3CN, DMF, MeOH, H2O, EtOH, EtOAc, CHCl3 and CH2Cl2 (5 mL) in the presence of 15 mg of Ti-MOF-UR under reflux condition (Fig. 7 a). Also, the model of reaction was studied by using different amounts of catalyst (Fig. 7b) and temperatures (Fig. 7c). The results of the reaction were not improved. The best of choice condition for the synthesis of (1A) was achieved in the presence of Ti-MOF-UR (15 mg) under solvent-free condition at 110 °C. After obtaining the optimal reaction conditions for the preparation of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives, various aromatic aldehydes were used to synthesize a wide range of these compounds (Table 1 ). The obtained yields show the catalytic performance of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst. All compounds were synthesized in high yields under mild and green reaction conditions. The final structure of the obtained products was confirmed using melting point, FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HR-MS techniques. The existence of a circular plate morphology with large dimensions and a high surface area of the catalyst has provided a suitable platform for the reaction. This suitable substrate makes the raw materials of the reaction to be well placed on the catalyst and activated by the urea groups in the catalyst, and the conditions for creating a product with high efficiency are provided. In the proposed mechanism, at first, 4‑hydroxy-2H-chroman-2-one is activated by the Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond. Then the carbonyl aldehyde group activated by the catalyst and by losing a H2O molecule, intermediate (I) is produced. In the next step, the 3-(4-chlorophenyl)−1H-pyrazol-5-amine is added to the intermediate (I), which is a Michael acceptor, and intermediate (II) is produced. In continued, intermediate (II) is converted to the intermediate (III) via tautomerism. Intermediate (III) is converted to intermediate (IV) via cyclization. In the final step (IV) becomes the final product by losing another H2O molecule (Scheme 3 ). The mechanism for the synthesis of henna-based pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines derivatives is carried out similarly. To prove the proper performance of the catalyst in the preparation of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives, the model of reaction was tested with other organic and inorganic catalysts which those obtained results are shown in Table 2 . The results showed that the efficiency and reaction time in the presence of the presented catalyst Ti-MOF-UR has a more suitable performance. On the other hand, the recyclability of the synthesized catalyst was investigated (Fig. 8 a). The results of Fig. 8a show that this catalyst can be reused 5 times without significant change in reaction efficiency and time, which can turn this feature of catalyst Ti-MOF-UR into a suitable catalyst for organic reactions. To prove this capability, XRD and FT-IR analyzes were taken from the reused catalyst. The results are shown in Fig. 8b & c. According to these results, few changes have been made in the structure of the catalyst and its proper stability can be well inferred. 4 Conclusion In this paper, we have reported Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst using the post-modification method of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The presented method has been presented a new class of porous catalysts for synthetic purposes. This catalyst was characterized by several techniques. The catalytic application of the presented catalyst at the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives with pyrazole, coumarin and henna‐based moieties were studied. Easy separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture, clean profile of the reaction, widespread synthesis of biologically active compounds with good to excellent yields are most important property of the methodology presented in this project. coredata.dc:description: A new H-bond Ti-MOF-based catalyst via the post-modification method of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) was synthesized. The catalytic role of Ti-MOF-UR is based on hydrogen-bond interaction. Ti-MOF-UR was used to synthesize pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines that contain the biological nuclei of pyrazole, henna and coumarin. The structure of the synthesized catalyst as well as the pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridine derivatives were approved by using various instrumental techniques such as melting point, FT-IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and HR-MS techniques.
coredata.dc:title: Application of Ti-MOF-UR as a new porous catalyst for the preparation of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline and pyrazolo[4,3-e]pyridines
